content.description: A fun climb if you like vertical bushwhacking. The crux is making it through the scrub oak. It doesn't get much traffic so expect a fair amount of grit.
content.protection:
Cams and slings. Belay from tree at top and then traverse climbers right to the anchors of the second pitch of

Angel Dust

. Make two rappels back to the ground.
content.location:
From the first anchor of

Angel Dust

, make a delicate traverse left to the crack with all the scrub oak protruding from it.

content.description: Classic E.A. climbing. first crux .11- hard crux on face above .12-
content.protection: #13 BD Stopper for first crux; you'll see it.
content.location:
To the right of

Byrd's Classic

.

climbs.name: Freebase
climbs.fa: Johnny Duran, Tim Kuss, & Jim DiNapoli, 1984

content.description:
Per

Ben Griffin

:

I did this route last summer, spring, or fall. I really don't remember. You climb the choss gully to climbers left of Angel Dust, then head up to a giant bolt. It is hard to see the bolt from the ground, but it is up there. The next piece of pro is a beaten in copperhead that looks like it is from the dinosaur era. Climb over the overhang and traverse right which is run out for the leader and follower, to another dirty crack. Then, the leader climbs up the crack and does a sketchy traverse out left to the sick, overhanging, hands to fist crack. I thought I was going to be the first person to climb this route in years, but when I got to the crack it was perfectly clean. It is an incredible crack pitch at East Animas, with its exposure and sustained crack climbing. The crack is much cleaner than Slave's Crack, which receives a lot more traffic.

Per

Dancesatmoonrise

:

The FA was by Johnny Duran. He showed it to Jim DiNapoli in 1984 and gave DiNapoli the lead. After yo-yo'ing the overhanging crack out of sheer fright, DiNapoli flamed out turning the top, Duran finished the lead, DiNapoli finished on second.

In those days, Duran used to regularly do the Watch Crystal wearing nothing but gym shorts, a chalk bag, a Walkman, and a rack with one stopper. The stopper was to put in at the belay to bring his GF up.
content.protection:
Standard East A rack.

Per

Ben Griffin

This route can now be done in one pitch. There are now 3 bolts protecting the face of this rock climb and two bolts for a belay. The route still feels pretty adventuresome.
content.location:
This is on the left side of the

Byrd's

area.

content.description:
P1. Climb up the corner and traverse left below a roof or take the wide-hand crack direct start (5.9). Follow the crack system to below another roof and traverse right. Finish up with a short splitter to a ledge with a bolted anchor.

P2. From the tree on the belay ledge, move left and climb the unprotected face. This pitch in seldom done.
content.protection:
Standard East A rack - #3 Camalot.

Bring an extra hand-sized cam if doing the direct start.
content.location:
Start left of the

Watch Crystal

and

Apple Cider

in a corner near a large tree.

content.description:
Bill apparently had been looking at this for years.  Finally inspired by the recent bolting at East A., he motivated.

Slap and compression your way through crimps and slopers up this arete.

We're not too sure about the grade but decided to start the bidding at 12+.  Who knows, it might be 12b or 13a.  No matter the grade, it's hella fun!
content.location:
This is the arete just left of

Angle Dust

.

content.description:
P1 - start up the corner, move right and follow the broken crack system to a bolted anchor near a large tree.

Variation: towards the top of the pitch, take the offwidth on the right and finish at the same anchor.

P2 - climb the smaller crack on the right with a small tree in it.

Variation - climb the offwidth on the left which rejoins the standard line.
content.protection: Standard East A rack - #3 Camalot. Bring a big cam if doing either of the OW variations.
content.location:
This route starts in a right-facing corner a little to the left of

Byrd's Classic

.
